instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPUBS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have a board here that had a small amount of liquid spill around J8500 . There is a short on F7000. I lifted F7000 and the short is on point 2 of the fuse the opposite side to the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is fine.
Found  <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> to be short , replaced .
Board now drawing 20v 270ma with no voltage on L7210,L7220.
L7270 has 1.05v (<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>) , cpu is heating up .
I tried replacing U[U]7100 but still the same.

Any ideas welcome[/U]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPUBS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
CPU got overvoltage when <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> was shorted on its high-side MOSFET.
Very likely is dead now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPUBS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Any way to tell 100% ?. Voltages seem to be present except for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> 0v and Cpu voltages.
L7220 is reading 4ohms to ground, L7210 is 5 ohms,L7410 8ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short on <SIGNAL>PPUBS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Unfortunately, this is not an exact science  :(.
No way to assure if CPU was letal damaged.
But your CPU received 100% an overvoltage there.
